reporting_cycle: The Director-General of the OPCW to report to the Security Council, through the Secretary-General, within 30 days and every month thereafter
summary:
The Government of Syria must: 
- Intensify the release of arbitrarily detained persons. 
- Ensure freedom of movement for journalists. 
- Respect freedom of association and the right to demonstrate peacefully. 

The Group agreed on principles for a Syrian-led transition, including: 
- A transition that offers a perspective for the future that can be shared by all. 
- Establishing clear steps towards the realization of that perspective. 
- Implementation in a climate of safety, stability, and calm. 
- A transition reached rapidly without further bloodshed and violence and is credible. 

The aspirations of the Syrian people include a State that meets their needs, but specifics were not detailed in this section of the document.
The Security Council resolution outlines requirements for a peaceful transition in the Syrian Arab Republic. A genuine democratic and pluralistic government must be established, allowing all political actors to compete fairly. This government must commit to international human rights standards, judicial independence, accountability, and the rule of law. 

The transitional governing body with full executive powers must be formed on the basis of mutual consent, including government and opposition members. A national dialogue process must be inclusive and meaningful, leading to a review of the constitutional order and free and fair multiparty elections.

Women must be fully represented in the transition. Safety, stability, and calm must be ensured through a permanent cessation of violence, protection of vulnerable groups, and humanitarian assistance.

The sovereignty, independence, unity, and territorial integrity of the Syrian Arab Republic must be respected. A peaceful dialogue and negotiation must resolve the conflict. All parties must commit to the six-point plan and engage with the Joint Special Envoy.

The international community will offer significant support for implementing an agreement, including an international assistance presence under a UN mandate if requested, and funds for reconstruction and rehabilitation.

Action Group members will engage with parties, apply joint pressure, and oppose further militarization. They will also emphasize the importance of an effective empowered interlocutor for the government.
